title: NSW park expansion for 3 vulnerable birds
text:
The home of the spotted harrier, the scarlet robin and the eastern bent wing in the NSW Central Tablelands has been extended by more than 500 hectares.

The state government on Tuesday announced the Avisford Nature Reserve, south of Mudgee, had been expanded by 504ha to 2,941ha.

Local MP Dugald Saunders said the expansion would help protect the threatened species.

In NSW, all three species have a conservation status of vulnerable - meaning they face a high risk of extinction in the medium-term future.

"Avisford comprises relatively high ridge lands typified by steep sloping gullies and hills with stringybark open forest and box woodlands," Mr Sauders said in a statement on Tuesday.

"These habitats provide for a diversity of plants and animals, especially birds and forest owls."

The government has prioritised the expansion of the NSW national park estate by 200,000ha over the next two years.
